bestBHT.bht: Everyone had their portion and were filled. The pieces of bread, not the scraps, were distributed, and each of the twelve disciples had a basketful left over. The fragments that remained after satisfying such a vast multitude were twelve times larger than the original portions, serving as a striking proof of the miracle. This miracle was intended to reveal God's blessing and provision, reminding us that if we are indolent and ungrateful, the only obstacle to having a sufficiency of food is ourselves.

Marvin Vincent: Juvenal, the Roman satirist, describes the grove of Numa, near the Capenian gate of Rome, as being 'let out to the Jews, whose furniture is a basket [χοπηινυσ] and some hay' (for a bed), 'Sat.' 3 14.

The word for basket used in relating the feeding of the four thousand (Matthew 14:37) is spuriv, a large provision - basket or hamper, of the kind used for letting Paul down over the wall at Damascus (Acts 9:25).
John Calvin: The fragments that remained after satisfying so vast a multitude of men were more than twelve times larger in quantity than what was at first put into their hands, and this contributed not a little to the splendor of the miracle.
Christ intended that, after the miracle had been wrought, a striking proof of it should still remain, which, after being refreshed by food, they might contemplate at leisure.
If we do not perceive that it is the blessing of God which multiplies the corn, that we may have a sufficiency of food, the only obstacle is, our own indolence and ingratitude.
Philip Schaff: Philip had said that 200 pennyworth of bread would only give each a little, but now all had received enough.
The pieces they distributed, pieces, not the refuse.
This circumstance mentioned by all four Evangelists was designed to impress the miracle upon the disciples.
Archibald T. Robertson: Not the scraps upon the ground, but the pieces broken by Jesus and still in the 'twelve baskets'.
Each of the twelve had a basketful left over.
John Gill: And they did all eat...everyone had their portion, and were filled...they had enough, and to spare..." (31 words)
The Jews used not to reckon it a meal, unless a man was filled...but here was fulness, and more left than was first had..." (33 words)
And they took up of the fragments that remained, twelve baskets full; according to the number of the disciples, every man had his basket full..." (29 words)

Everyone had their portion and were filled. The pieces of bread, not the scraps, were distributed, and each of the twelve disciples had a basketful left over. The fragments that remained after satisfying such a vast multitude were twelve times larger than the original portions, serving as a striking proof of the miracle.
